bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 2, 1900

div1.p: Reed gives instructions on gardening at Keewaydin. He also discusses financial affairs.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 2, 1900
div1.opener:
No. 12
Monday,
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba,
July 2nd, 1900
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
Well, to be
sure the dear lady of dear
Keewaydin is surpassing
herself! Two sweet letters
again, to-day -- those of June
27th and 28th and they were both
just as interesting as they could
be. I didn't exactly relish about
being told of that Snap-bean
and potato salad, as it made
my mouth a little moist!
Still, I am glad to know that
my sweet girls enjoyed it
so much. Those strawberry
preserves, also, touched a
very tender spot! So, old Mr
Keewaydin has been calling
occasionally, has he? He is
apt to call now and then- Here
the South wind is the most
important breeze and it is sur-
prising how cool & refreshing
it is. What you told me
about the shower and the grow-
ing plants was so interes-
ting- I can see the dear place
& everything as it is just as
if I were there! I know that
Grape Arbor must begin to
look so pretty- Have you yet
had snap-beans from your
own vines? I can hardly
think so- That you could
find any new potatoes was
really surprising, as I had thought
that you would yet have to
wait a week or moore.
Tell Jacob that the heavy
shower patted that earth
down on the corn and not my hoe-
If he will work the corn
every week, pulling the earth
to it some, you will soon
see how fast it will
grow- Don't eat it all up
before I get there- We get
none here, although it should
be raised in abundance.
A small cabbage, literally
no bigger than your fist, costs
15 to 25 cts! Every vegetable
is dreadfully expensive in
Cuba- Even potatoes, and
bananas are hardly cheaper
than in the U.S. Pineapples
are very good and not
unreasonable in price- So
you are still picking berries
from the patch? It won't
be long before you will
begin to have raspberries
and black-berries- You must
put down the date when you
get your first ones- Per-
haps, after all, roses will
grow well at our dear
home- Certainly Mrs. Roach's
looked splendidly- Hurrah
for the festive family of blue-
birds! They are more at-
tached to people than I had thought.

P.S. I think that you had
better mail your deposit
book to Mr C. J. Meyers
Army Medical Museum,
& ask him to have Beech-
ner take it to Riggs Bank
& get my June pay, $339.67,
credited to your account,
& then remail the Deposit
book to you- I left the
pay accounts with the
paymaster & he promised
to place the am't. to your
Credit, June 30th, but it
is just as well to have
the Credit entered on your
Book- What a beautiful
Morning this is after the
beautiful rain of last
evening- Here I sit in
my Pajamas while the
delicious breeze is so
cool that I must close
my windows to shut it
out- Presently I shall go
in to the dining-room & re-
gale myself on the tooth-
some mango -- Boo! Boo!
to you fat farmer-lady and
chubby little Dog-Trainer-
Devotedly, Papa Do I write often
enough?
Boo!!

WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.

Would you believe,
lovie, dear, that your
old Mr Mantee overslept
himself, this morning, and that
it is now 6,30 o'clock a,m,?
I have just had my delicious
shower bath and must hurry
& finish my letter before
7 o'clock, as the Postman
comes promptly at that
hour- I can scarcely be-
lieve that it was two(2)
weeks ago, this afternoon,
that I said good-bye to
Fat Farmer lady & plump
piano-player at dear Kee-
waydin- The time here sim-
ply flies- I never saw
anything like it- While I
think of it, and to return
to farming, I think that if
it becomes dry, you will
have to let Jacob pull
some of the leaves & manure
back around the little fruit-
trees, as it serves as a
mulch & to protect their
roots in hot weather.
It was all right to have
them nicely worked around
and you were a dear, smart
farmer lady to have thought
about it. Now, lovie, dear,
you know that the supposed
Holy-hock that I planted
was not a Squash? What
kind of a squash? Not a
regular, old fashioned cim-
lin? I don't believe it!
The word “rustler” is
proper & in correct form,
but it does not sufficient-
ly describe Johnnie Moore's
movements- You should have
said that he was a Hust-
ler from Hustlerville!
How does the fence look, now
that he has built a con-
siderable part of it?
Be certain to point out
to him that beautiful plant,
and don't let him destroy
it- Am glad that auntie
will soon be on the Mountain.
you never told me what
decision Mr Moore came
too as to the pony- Did he
take it? or did you return
it to Cap't. Norwood? Has
Blossom returned Mary's
call yet? She certainly should
do it- I know that your
morning at dear Keewaydin
cannot be any more beau-
tiful than it is here, this
morning, and the beautiful,
blue ocean is so lovely
to look at- You must come
down & take a peep next
January- It's nearly seven,
Love & Kisses for my sweet
Farmer lady and dear little
chicken-raiser- Regards to
Jacob, Cora & Carrie- write-often.
Boo! Boo!
